item.title: Example Page 1
item.description:

item.title: Example Talk
item.description:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.

Slides can be added in a few ways:

  • Create slides using Academic's Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.

Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.

item.title: Ripple Effects of Prizewinning in Science
item.description:
Click the Cite button above to demo the feature to enable visitors to import publication metadata into their reference management software.
Click the Slides button above to demo Academic's Markdown slides feature.

Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.

item.title: County-Level Climate Risk Index for Banking System Vulnerability
item.description:
Matched meteorological station data (temperature, precipitation, wind speed, SPEI) from year 2002-2022 to Chinese county boundaries within a set threshold

Utilized Inverse Distance Weighting (IDW) to calculate daily maximum and minimum temperatures, 20h-20h cumulative precipitation, maximum wind speed, and Standardized Precipitation Evapotranspiration Index (SPEI) for each county using ArcGIS, R, and Python

Assigned weights to different climate factors (# of consecutive extreme heat days, # of consecutive extreme cold days, # of rainstorm days, SPEI levels, # of tropical storm days) using Kolmogorov–Arnold Networks (KAN) and empirical methods to construct a county-level climate risk index

Assessed the vulnerability of banks to climate risks across different regions by evaluating their exposure, sensitivity, and adaptive capacity, following the framework established by the IPCC

item.title: Spillover Effects of Climate Physical Risk on Supply-chain Networks
item.description:
Investigated the climate risk impact on suppliers and customers and developed effective risk management strategies by constructing the C-Vine-Copula model

Fit the marginal distributions of climate variables and explored the tail dependence between climate risk factors affecting suppliers and the financial performance of customers in the supply-chain networks

Utilized the first-order network coupling and second-order network coupling index to analyze the impact of climate risk on the embeddedness of supply-chain networks, finding extreme high and low temperatures can increase the dispersion of customers within the supply-chain networks

item.title: Quantifying the multiscale side-effects of retraction across countries
item.description:
Utilized bibliometric tools and data science techniques to study variations in the citation impacts across different countries, disciplines, reasons for retraction, open access or not, and institutions ranking (QS).

Applied complex network analysis to assess structural changes in the citation networks among nations before and after retractions, revealing dynamic adjustments in knowledge flows.

Utilized DID and Fixed Effect Regression methodologies to focus on analyzing the impact of retracted papers from China, and identified significant effects within the fields of CS, Engineering, Material Science, and Medicine.

Employed statistical methods and network analysis to investigate the effects of retractions on the previous publications of retracted authors, references within retracted papers, subsequent papers citing the retracted articles, and co-authors’ publications.

Contributed to policy-making by providing empirical evidence used to reform practices surrounding retractions, leading to more robust publication integrity protocols and increased accountability in scholarly communications.

item.title: Ripple Effects of Prizewinning in Science
item.description:
Investigated the spillover effects and Matthew effects of prizewinning on the citations of both winners and their coauthors’ papers using fixed effect regression analysis techniques to isolate the effects of awards from other variables.

Matched 3 million data points related to the publications and citations of winners and their coauthors using SQL and Python for data manipulation and dynamic matching algorithms.

Identified factors influencing the prizewinning effect on winners and coauthors, including disciplines, award year, publication recency, and award age and winner’s gender by using polynomial regression.

Employed Difference-in-Differences (DID) method to analyze the individual treatment effect of prizewinning, utilizing Stata and R for statistical analysis to ensure robustness in the findings.

Analyzed the mediation effects of prizewinning on coauthors’ papers via winner-coauthor network ties, employing network analysis tools such as Gephi and Python's NetworkX library to visualize and quantify network changes.

Authored the paper “Ripple effects of prizewinning in science,” as the first author.

item.title: Transmission Mechanism of Geopolitical Risks on the Energy Market.
item.description:
Developed a two-stage geopolitical risk analysis approach, integrating statistics, econometrics, macroeconomics, and behavioral finance theories, to analyze the transmission mechanisms of geopolitical risk to the oil market.

Collected oil-related data from Thomson Reuters, WIND, Federal Reserve Bank of St.Louis, and U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), enabling rapid collection and extraction of valid data.

Utilized the time-varying parametric vector autoregressive (TVPVAR) model to demonstrate how geopolitical risk influences oil prices through various transmission paths, including micro and macro media—including oil supply, demand, inventory, speculative behavior, and economic activity.

Demonstrated that speculative behavior intensifies during periods of elevated geopolitical risk, significantly impacting oil prices through fluctuations in market positions (long and short).

Identified that the predominant effect of geopolitical tensions is to drive up oil prices by dampening economic activity, establishing a critical pathway of influence.

Co-published the paper Transmission Mechanisms of Geopolitical Risks to the Crude Oil Market—a pioneering two-stage geopolitical risk analysis approach as the first author.

item.title: Transmission Mechanisms of Geopolitical Risks to the Crude Oil Market -- A Pioneering Two-Stage Geopolitical Risk Analysis Approach
item.description:
Click the Cite button above to demo the feature to enable visitors to import publication metadata into their reference management software.
Click the Slides button above to demo Academic's Markdown slides feature.

Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.

item.title: Conformal Prediction for Dynamic Time Series of Oil Price
item.description:
Utilized a combination of Random Forest, Decision Tree, Gradient Boosting Tree, and Graph Attention Network models within the conformal prediction framework to forecast oil prices. Incorporated geopolitical factors for enhanced insights into energy market dynamics.

Developed aggregation functions to integrate multiple predictions, facilitating statistical inference and the construction of prediction intervals for future oil prices, with an emphasis on managing uncertainty.

item.title: Application of Game Theory and Network Science in Climate Change Analysis.
item.description:
Conducted a comprehensive review of over 20 scholarly papers focused on the application of evolutionary and behavioral game-theoretic models in developing strategies for low-carbon energy trading and enhancing global climate action.

Employed network science techniques to analyze the strategic interactions and commitment levels among countries in international climate change mitigation efforts, mapping complex networks to illustrate these relationships.

Developed data-driven frameworks to summarize how climate-related risks (both physical and transitional) propagate through financial markets, impacting credit, market, liquidity, and operational risks across different geographic regions.

Utilized system dynamics modeling to investigate the cascading effects of extreme climate events on economic growth within interconnected climate-social systems, highlighting the role of network analysis in understanding systemic vulnerabilities and response mechanisms.

item.title: Management of Energy Systems for Sustainable Development.
item.description:
Conducted in-depth review of 20+ papers & reports (e.g., WB, IPCC, IMF) on circular economy, energy transition, international energy policy, net zero strategy, and sustainable development.

Analyzed green finance's role in driving renewable energy investment & authored insightful essay on energy transition opportunities & threats, providing recommendations for stakeholders.

item.title: Robust inference of mixed regression model based on non-convex penalty likelihood method.
item.description:
Developed a robust logistic regression method based on non-convex penalty regression by introducing a mean-shift parameter, improving predictive performance significantly,

Assisted to design an innovative iteration-based threshold embedded [Θ-IPOD] algorithm for concurrent outlier detection and robust parameter estimation.

Designed and administered a survey comprising 490 responses to investigate consumer purchasing tendencies and influencing factors within the influencer economy.

Explored factors affecting consumer decision-making in the influencer economy, including personal characteristics, awareness of influencers and their products, purchasing behavior, and factors considered during influencer recommendations.

Conducted an in-depth data analysis using backward stepwise regression to select relevant variables and robust logistic regression algorithms to assess factors influencing consumer purchase behavior regarding web celebrity products, focusing on Organization and Management.

Employed advanced statistical tools and R software to ensure the reliability and effectiveness of the data processing and analysis, demonstrating the robustness and efficacy of the methods in understanding the impact of the web celebrity economy on consumer behavior.

Co-authored the paper “基于非凸惩罚回归的稳健Logistic回归模型及其实证” as the lead author.

item.title: Robust Logistic Regression Model and Its Empirical Results Based on Nonconvex Penalized Regression
item.description:
Click the Cite button above to demo the feature to enable visitors to import publication metadata into their reference management software.
Click the Slides button above to demo Academic's Markdown slides feature.

Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.

item.title: Writing technical content in Academic
item.description:
Academic is designed to give technical content creators a seamless experience. You can focus on the content and Academic handles the rest.

Highlight your code snippets, take notes on math classes, and draw diagrams from textual representation.

On this page, you'll find some examples of the types of technical content that can be rendered with Academic.

Examples

Code

Academic supports a Markdown extension for highlighting code syntax. You can enable this feature by toggling the highlight option in your config/_default/params.toml file.

```python
import pandas as pd
data = pd.read_csv("data.csv")
data.head()
```

renders as

import pandas as pd
data = pd.read_csv("data.csv")
data.head()

Math

Academic supports a Markdown extension for $\LaTeX$ math. You can enable this feature by toggling the math option in your config/_default/params.toml file.

To render inline or block math, wrap your LaTeX math with $...$ or $$...$$, respectively.

Example math block:

$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ 
\left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T 
\left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}
{\left \|\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right \|^2}$$

renders as

$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}{\left |\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right |^2}$$

Example inline math $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$ renders as $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$.

Example multi-line math using the \\ math linebreak:

$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \\
1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$

renders as

$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \
1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$

Diagrams

Academic supports a Markdown extension for diagrams. You can enable this feature by toggling the diagram option in your config/_default/params.toml file or by adding diagram: true to your page front matter.

An example flowchart:

```mermaid
graph TD
A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round)
B --> C{Decision}
C -->|One| D[Result 1]
C -->|Two| E[Result 2]
```

renders as

graph TD
A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round)
B --> C{Decision}
C -->|One| D[Result 1]
C -->|Two| E[Result 2]

An example sequence diagram:

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you?
loop Healthcheck
    John->>John: Fight against hypochondria
end
Note right of John: Rational thoughts!
John-->>Alice: Great!
John->>Bob: How about you?
Bob-->>John: Jolly good!
```

renders as

sequenceDiagram
Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you?
loop Healthcheck
    John->>John: Fight against hypochondria
end
Note right of John: Rational thoughts!
John-->>Alice: Great!
John->>Bob: How about you?
Bob-->>John: Jolly good!

An example Gantt diagram:

```mermaid
gantt
section Section
Completed :done,    des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08
Active        :active,  des2, 2014-01-07, 3d
Parallel 1   :         des3, after des1, 1d
Parallel 2   :         des4, after des1, 1d
Parallel 3   :         des5, after des3, 1d
Parallel 4   :         des6, after des4, 1d
```

renders as

gantt
section Section
Completed :done,    des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08
Active        :active,  des2, 2014-01-07, 3d
Parallel 1   :         des3, after des1, 1d
Parallel 2   :         des4, after des1, 1d
Parallel 3   :         des5, after des3, 1d
Parallel 4   :         des6, after des4, 1d

An example class diagram:

```mermaid
classDiagram
Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool
<<interface>> Class01
Class09 --> C2 : Where am i?
Class09 --* C3
Class09 --|> Class07
Class07 : equals()
Class07 : Object[] elementData
Class01 : size()
Class01 : int chimp
Class01 : int gorilla
class Class10 {
  <<service>>
  int id
  size()
}
```

renders as

classDiagram
Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool
<<interface>> Class01
Class09 --> C2 : Where am i?
Class09 --* C3
Class09 --|> Class07
Class07 : equals()
Class07 : Object[] elementData
Class01 : size()
Class01 : int chimp
Class01 : int gorilla
class Class10 {
  <<service>>
  int id
  size()
}

An example state diagram:

```mermaid
stateDiagram
[*] --> Still
Still --> [*]
Still --> Moving
Moving --> Still
Moving --> Crash
Crash --> [*]
```

renders as

stateDiagram
[*] --> Still
Still --> [*]
Still --> Moving
Moving --> Still
Moving --> Crash
Crash --> [*]

Todo lists

You can even write your todo lists in Academic too:

- [x] Write math example
- [x] Write diagram example
- [ ] Do something else

renders as

  • Write math example
  • Write diagram example
  • Do something else

Tables

Represent your data in tables:

| First Header  | Second Header |
| ------------- | ------------- |
| Content Cell  | Content Cell  |
| Content Cell  | Content Cell  |

renders as

First Header Second Header
Content Cell Content Cell
Content Cell Content Cell

Asides

Academic supports a shortcode for asides, also referred to as notices, hints, or alerts. By wrapping a paragraph in {{% alert note %}} ... {{% /alert %}}, it will render as an aside.

{{% alert note %}}
A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers.
{{% /alert %}}

renders as

A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers.

Did you find this page helpful? Consider sharing it 🙌

item.title: Display Jupyter Notebooks with Academic
item.description:
from IPython.core.display import Image
Image('https://www.python.org/static/community_logos/python-logo-master-v3-TM-flattened.png')


print("Welcome to Academic!")

Welcome to Academic!

Install Python and JupyterLab

Install Anaconda which includes Python 3 and JupyterLab.

Alternatively, install JupyterLab with pip3 install jupyterlab.

Create or upload a Jupyter notebook

Run the following commands in your Terminal, substituting <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER> and <SHORT-POST-TITLE> with the file path to your Academic website folder and a short title for your blog post (use hyphens instead of spaces), respectively:

mkdir -p <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/
cd <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/
jupyter lab index.ipynb

The jupyter command above will launch the JupyterLab editor, allowing us to add Academic metadata and write the content.

Edit your post metadata

The first cell of your Jupter notebook will contain your post metadata (front matter).

In Jupter, choose Markdown as the type of the first cell and wrap your Academic metadata in three dashes, indicating that it is YAML front matter:

---
title: My post's title
date: 2019-09-01

# Put any other Academic metadata here...
---

Edit the metadata of your post, using the documentation as a guide to the available options.

To set a featured image, place an image named featured into your post's folder.

For other tips, such as using math, see the guide on writing content with Academic.

Convert notebook to Markdown

jupyter nbconvert index.ipynb --to markdown --NbConvertApp.output_files_dir=.

Example

This post was created with Jupyter. The orginal files can be found at https://github.com/gcushen/hugo-academic/tree/master/exampleSite/content/post/jupyter

item.title: Slides
item.description:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic

Academic | Documentation

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let's make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask

Documentation

item.title: Academic: the website builder for Hugo
item.description:
Create a free website with Academic using Markdown, Jupyter, or RStudio. Choose a beautiful color theme and build anything with the Page Builder - over 40 widgets, themes, and language packs included!

Check out the latest demo of what you'll get in less than 10 minutes, or view the showcase of personal, project, and business sites.

  • 👉 Get Started
  • 📚 View the documentation
  • 💬 Ask a question on the forum
  • 👥 Chat with the community
  • 🐦 Twitter: @source_themes @GeorgeCushen #MadeWithAcademic
  • 💡 Request a feature or report a bug
  • ⬆️ Updating? View the Update Guide and Release Notes
  • ❤ Support development of Academic:
    • ☕️ Donate a coffee
    • 💵 Become a backer on Patreon
    • 🖼️ Decorate your laptop or journal with an Academic sticker
    • 👕 Wear the T-shirt
    • 👩‍💻 Contribute

Key features:

  • Page builder - Create anything with widgets and elements
  • Edit any type of content - Blog posts, publications, talks, slides, projects, and more!
  • Create content in Markdown, Jupyter, or RStudio
  • Plugin System - Fully customizable color and font themes
  • Display Code and Math - Code highlighting and LaTeX math supported
  • Integrations - Google Analytics, Disqus commenting, Maps, Contact Forms, and more!
  • Beautiful Site - Simple and refreshing one page design
  • Industry-Leading SEO - Help get your website found on search engines and social media
  • Media Galleries - Display your images and videos with captions in a customizable gallery
  • Mobile Friendly - Look amazing on every screen with a mobile friendly version of your site
  • Multi-language - 15+ language packs including English, 中文, and Português
  • Multi-user - Each author gets their own profile page
  • Privacy Pack - Assists with GDPR
  • Stand Out - Bring your site to life with animation, parallax backgrounds, and scroll effects
  • One-Click Deployment - No servers. No databases. Only files.

Themes

Academic comes with automatic day (light) and night (dark) mode built-in. Alternatively, visitors can choose their preferred mode - click the sun/moon icon in the top right of the Demo to see it in action! Day/night mode can also be disabled by the site admin in params.toml.

Choose a stunning theme and font for your site. Themes are fully customizable.

Ecosystem

  • Academic Admin: An admin tool to import publications from BibTeX or import assets for an offline site
  • Academic Scripts: Scripts to help migrate content to new versions of Academic

Install

You can choose from one of the following four methods to install:

  • one-click install using your web browser (recommended)
  • install on your computer using Git with the Command Prompt/Terminal app
  • install on your computer by downloading the ZIP files
  • install on your computer with RStudio

Then personalize and deploy your new site.

Updating

View the Update Guide.

Feel free to star the project on Github to help keep track of updates.

License

Copyright 2016-present George Cushen.

Released under the MIT license.
